item.title: ‘Hadinelentu’ movie review: A gripping reflection of society’s unfair power structures
item.description: The article discusses the film "Hadinelentu" directed by Prithvi Konanur, which explores societal issues such as gender and economic inequalities. The story revolves around two teenagers, Deepa and Hari, whose leaked sex tape creates a controversy. The film sheds light on how individuals from privileged backgrounds are treated differently compared to those from oppressed communities. Deepa is forced to sacrifice her dreams and face the harsh consequences, while Hari's family has multiple options to escape the situation. As the plot unfolds, the film reveals unexpected character developments and showcases the complexities of the country's legal system. "Hadinelentu" serves as a reflection of our times, highlighting the impact of social media and the need for discussions on these pressing issues. The performances of the cast, including Sudha Belawadi, Bhavani Prakash, and Nagendra Sha, contribute to the movie's realistic tone. Overall, the article praises the film for its impactful storytelling and its ability to address important social themes effectively.

item.title: ‘Blue Star’ movie review: Ashok Selvan, Shanthnu knock it out of the park in this powerful sports drama
item.description: The article discusses the film "Blue Star," directed by S Jayakumar and presented by Pa Ranjith, which is a social examination through the lens of cricket. The story revolves around two angsty youngsters from rival communities, Rajesh and Ranjith, who find themselves locked in conflict both on and off the cricket ground. The film explores themes of social hierarchy, casteism, and the power of sports to break down barriers. It portrays the characters as young boys with their own desires and dreams, highlighting the complexity of their identities. The writing focuses on the character arcs of Rajesh and Ranjith, as well as the ideological clash between them. Secondary characters also play important roles, such as Immanuel, a former cricketer, and Anandhi, Ranjith's love interest, who advocates for empowering women in sports. The performances of Ashok Selvan and Shanthnu Bhagyaraj are praised for their swag and charisma, effectively portraying vulnerability and ego. Overall, the film is seen as an achievement in mainstream cinema, reflecting the call for equality, peace, and love for all.

item.title: ‘Singapore Saloon’ movie review: RJ Balaji’s partly funny drama suffers from identity crisis
item.description: Article found but Couldn't summarize ‘Singapore Saloon’ features a mindless yet hilarious first half that transforms into a messy, cluttered and unnecessarily preachy second half

item.title: ‘Malaikottai Vaaliban’ movie review: Lijo Jose Pellissery and Mohanlal’s epic is nowhere closer to the sum of its parts
item.description: The article discusses the film "Malaikottai Vaaliban," directed by Lijo Jose Pellissery and starring Mohanlal. The author praises various aspects of the film, including the visually stunning cinematography, captivating sound design, and notable performances. However, despite these individual strengths, the article suggests that the film falls short of its potential due to weak writing and underdeveloped characters. The storyline, set in a timeless landscape, follows the journey of Vaaliban, a fighter who travels from town to town, facing adversaries and gaining admirers. The article criticizes the screenplay for feeling sluggish and rushed towards the end, with several plot elements packed into the last half-hour. While Mohanlal's portrayal is praised for bringing believability to his character, it is noted that even his role could have been better written. Danish Sait's character receives positive feedback as one of the few well-written characters in the film. The article concludes by highlighting the director's attempt to bring something new to the film but expresses disappointment with the overall result, hoping for more substance in any future sequels.

item.title: ‘My Demon’ K-drama review: Song Kang and Kim Yoo-jung light up the screen in a show that loses steam midway
item.description: The article discusses the K-drama series called "My Demon," praising its initial success but also highlighting the need for more K-dramas to adopt a shorter 12-episode format. The show follows a chaebol heiress named Do Do-hee and Jeong Gu-Won, who is revealed to be the devil. They enter into a contract marriage where Gu-Won acts as her bodyguard. The article commends the lead actors, Song Kang and Kim Yoo-jung, for their chemistry and screen presence. However, it criticizes the show's writing and pacing in the latter half, which becomes convoluted and includes unnecessary complications. Despite these flaws, the fantasy-romance genre and the performances of the lead actors make "My Demon" worth watching. The entire series is available for streaming on Netflix.

item.title: ‘Saindhav’ movie review: The emotional drama is fine, if only the thriller had been smarter
item.description: The Telugu film "Saindhav," written and directed by Sailesh Kolanu, revolves around the character SaiKo, portrayed by Venkatesh Daggubati. The film follows SaiKo's mission to save his daughter while dealing with sinister happenings in the port city. While the film has its brighter aspects, such as interesting characters and some captivating moments, it falls short of being a truly riveting emotional action drama. Nonetheless, Venkatesh delivers a strong performance, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui's character adds authenticity to the story. The cinematography and portrayal of the fictional city are noteworthy. However, overall, the film could have been more engaging and smarter in its execution.

item.title: ‘Guntur Kaaram’ movie review: Mahesh Babu delivers the same old dish, served with an extra dose of chillies
item.description: The article discusses the Telugu film 'Guntur Kaaram' directed by Trivikram Srinivas and starring Mahesh Babu. The film aims to be an emotional family entertainer and a mass/masala film but falls short in delivering an engaging narrative. While Mahesh Babu gives a commendable performance, the supporting actors are given uninteresting characters. The two leading women have forgettable roles, and the clash between Mahesh Babu and Prakash Raj's characters lacks entertainment value. The film also faces criticism for its visuals and lack of innovation in action sequences. Overall, 'Guntur Kaaram' is considered an improvement compared to Trivikram's previous film, but it still lacks reasons for celebration.

item.title: ‘HanuMan’ movie review: This homegrown superhero film is largely a fun ride
item.description: The article discusses the film "HanuMan," directed by Prasanth Varma, which follows the familiar superhero story arc. The protagonist, Hanumanthu, gains superpowers and faces off against a villain, Michael. The film incorporates elements from the Ramayana and features pop culture references and entertaining segments typical of Telugu cinema. While the visual effects are not consistently impressive, the narrative keeps the audience engaged. The article praises Teja Sajja's performance as Hanumanthu and highlights the portrayal of strong female characters. The film combines faith and mainstream cinema tropes while delivering moments that resonate with the audience. Overall, "HanuMan" is an enjoyable homegrown superhero story that doesn't exploit religious sentiments.

item.title: Nikon Z f camera review | Retro-styled, built for low-light captures
item.description: The article discusses the Nikon Z f, a new mirrorless camera that draws inspiration from the Nikon FM2 film camera. It features a vintage design with a magnesium alloy body and a leather-textured finish. The camera has a wide ISO range, allowing for low-light photography, and utilizes deep learning technology for autofocus. While it performs well in street photography and portrait shots, it may not be ideal for capturing fast-moving objects. The camera also offers features like monochrome picture controls and connectivity to the Snapbridge app for easy image transfer. Overall, the Nikon Z f is a well-designed camera suitable for low-light and everyday photography.

item.title: ‘Double Engine’ movie review: An unhinged coming-of-age tale from rural Telangana

The story follows Danny, a shared auto driver, who embarks on a journey to capture a double-headed snake with the help of his friends. The film portrays the contrast between Hyderabad and the rural village of Tatipalli, showcasing different aspects of life and culture. The article praises the film's visuals, music, and realistic portrayal of characters. It concludes by highlighting the film's progression from a slice-of-life story to an adventure drama and coming-of-age tale.

item.title: ‘Society of the Snow’ movie review: A simple, affecting look at the 1972 Andes flight disaster
item.description: Society of the Snow is a film directed by JA Bayona that tells the story of the 1972 Andes flight disaster. It focuses on the survival and resilience of the rugby team members who were stranded in the freezing Andes mountains after the crash. The film explores their journey over the next two months as they struggle to stay alive and eventually resort to extreme measures. Bayona's approach to the story is refreshing, as it emphasizes the human spirit and avoids sensationalism. The film does a good job of balancing despair and hope, and it stands out from other narratives by raising unanswerable questions about survival and hope in the face of adversity. Society of the Snow is available for streaming on Netflix.

item.title: ‘The Curse’ series review: Emma Stone is astounding in this ink-black satire
item.description: "The Curse" is a scripted show created by Nathan Fielder and Benny Safdie, starring Emma Stone and Fielder. Whitney and Asher Siegel are a married couple who aim to develop a crime-ridden neighborhood into an inclusive community on a reality show called Fliplanthropy. The show explores Whitney's conflict between doing what's right for the planet and her self-interest, while also delving into the curse affecting the land and its people. The show features a reality TV aesthetic and tackles themes of self-awareness and corporate comedy. "The Curse" is currently streaming on Lionsgate Play.

item.description: The article discusses the spin-off series titled "Berlin" based on the popular Netflix show "Money Heist." While the original series focused on a heist and the robbers' personal lives, "Berlin" primarily revolves around the love lives of the main characters. The heist itself, involving the stealing of 44 million in jewels, is completed within the first half of the 8-episode series. The article criticizes the shallow plot, uninteresting heist sequence, and underdeveloped secondary characters in "Berlin." It concludes by stating that the series fails to capitalize on interesting ideas and ultimately wastes the viewer's time.

item.title: New forays into abhinaya and nritta at the Dance for Dance Festival
item.description: The article discusses the performances at the Kalavaahini Festival - Dance for Dance 2023, held at Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, Mylapore. The festival featured Koodiyattam, Mohiniyattam, and Odissi dances. Nepathya Sreehari Chakyar, the recipient of the Kalavaahini Junior Fellowship, performed 'Gajendra Moksham,' a Koodiyattam production based on three story tracks. The article also highlights Neena Prasad's Mohiniyattam presentation titled 'Swathi Muthyam,' which consisted of compositions by Swati Tirunal. Additionally, Madhavi Mudgal's group choreographies in Odissi were showcased at the festival. The performances were well-received, with the artists displaying their expertise and skill in their respective dance forms. [[1]]

item.title: What made Trichur Brothers’ concert experiential?
item.description:
The article discusses a concert by the Trichur Brothers at Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan's Margazhi festival. The vocalists employed three strategies to enhance the concert experience. First, they sang a bhajan with introductory sketches using only the notes of Bihag, which the audience intoned back. Second, they performed a detailed niraval along the centrepiece, showcasing their skill in swaraprastara. Third, they included a tani avartanam, where the gathering was encouraged to join in by tapping for the two-kalai Adi tala. The concert also featured the assistance of teenaged violinist V.S.P. Gayathri Sivani and the mridangam player Trichur R. Mohan. The article highlights the brothers' rendition of the ragam-tanam-keertanam in Hemavathi and their performance of the kriti 'Shri kantimatim'. The concert concluded with the songs 'Narayana te' and 'Harivarasanam' [[1]].
Please note that the summary is based on the search results and may not capture all the details of the article.

item.title: Ranjani and Gayatri’s concert was high on sowkhyam
item.description:
**Summary:**
The article discusses a concert by the renowned Carnatic vocalists Ranjani and Gayathri at the Music Academy's 97th annual conference and concerts in 2023. The sisters have been at the top of their field for a decade and continue to strive for excellence in their classical exploration. The concert showcased their vibrant and scholarly elements, with a focus on skill and variations in delivery. The article highlights specific performances and compositions from the concert, such as the adjustment in tempo and the inclusion of a Thiruarutpa of Ramalinga Adigalar. The concert also gave space and respect to co-artists, such as M. Rajeev on the violin and Manoj Siva on the mridangam. Overall, the concert demonstrated the sisters' ability to strike a balance between vibrancy and contemplation, tradition and innovation, and showcased their musical nuances more profoundly [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/music/ranjani-and-gayatris-concert-was-high-on-sowkhyam/article67697832.ece).
#### Ranjani and Gayathri's Concert at the Music Academy's 97th Annual Conference and Concerts 2023
Ranjani and Gayathri, renowned Carnatic vocalists, performed at the Music Academy's 97th annual conference and concerts in 2023. The concert showcased their vibrant and scholarly elements, with a focus on skill and variations in delivery. The sisters have been at the top of their field for a decade and continue to strive for excellence in their classical exploration [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/music/ranjani-and-gayatris-concert-was-high-on-sowkhyam/article67697832.ece).
#### Notable Performances and Compositions
The concert featured several notable performances and compositions. One noticeable change was the adjustment in tempo, with a focus on skill and variations in delivery. The song 'Ekadantam bhaje ham' (Bilahari, Dikshitar) demonstrated this adjustment, with a teaser quota of swaras. The raga Pantuvarali was given a lift with sensitive phrases from Ranjani, including the liberal use of Panchama varjam, which gave it a Hindustani feel. The concert also included a Thiruarutpa of Ramalinga Adigalar, set to music by their guru, P. S. Narayanaswamy, in Adi, tisra nadai. The composition was enhanced by the niraval at 'Enniru kan maniye' and PSN's laya-laced chittaswara. Other compositions performed included 'Kandu kandu' in Kamboji (Purandaradasa) and 'Vijayambike' (Vijayanagari) of Muthiah Bhagavathar. The concert also featured a classic alapana of Bhairavi and an RTP in Nalinakanti, which included a beautifully rendered thanam, an artistic pallavi in Adi, and a multi-raga swara by Gayatri. The concert showcased the sisters' ability to strike a balance between vibrancy and contemplation, tradition and innovation, and captured their musical nuances more profoundly [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/music/ranjani-and-gayatris-concert-was-high-on-sowkhyam/article67697832.ece).
#### Co-Artistes and Their Contributions
The concert also gave space and respect to co-artists who are competent in their own right. M. Rajeev, the violinist, showcased his musical maturity in all raga alapana segments, especially in Nalinakanti. Manoj Siva, on the mridangam, played a complementary role, and the tani with Chandrasekara Sharma on the ghatam was bright and skillful. The concert also included a virutham in Mohanam and the Papanasam Sivan kriti, 'Nambikketavar evarayya' in Hindolam. Despite the time constraints, an abhang was also performed during the concert. The inclusion of co-artists and their contributions added to the overall richness of the performance [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/music/ranjani-and-gayatris-concert-was-high-on-sowkhyam/article67697832.ece).
#### Conclusion
Ranjani and Gayathri's concert at the Music Academy's 97th annual conference and concerts in 2023 showcased their vibrant and scholarly elements, with a focus on skill and variations in delivery. The concert featured notable performances and compositions, including adjustments in tempo, sensitive phrases, and a multi-raga swara. The inclusion of co-artists and their contributions added further richness to the performance. Overall, the concert demonstrated the sisters' ability to strike a balance between vibrancy and contemplation, tradition and innovation, and captured their musical nuances more profoundly [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/music/ranjani-and-gayatris-concert-was-high-on-sowkhyam/article67697832.ece).

item.title: How can dancers bring their art alive on stage?
item.description: The article discusses the Kalavaahini Dance for Dance festival, which took place on December 22, 2023, at Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan under the auspices of Kartik Fine Arts. The festival aims to provide opportunities for dancers and ensure they are paid professionally for their work. Classical dance forms, such as Bharatanatyam and Kathak, offer a structured framework for creating and connecting with the audience. The performances at the festival drew inspiration from bhakti literature, both old and new. Aditi Mangaldas presented a production called 'Immersed,' exploring the abstractness amidst the lore of Krishna. Lakshmi Parthasarathy Athreya premiered 'The dot that moved,' which used the Shiva Tandava stotram. The performances were accompanied by a team of supporting artists, including musicians and lighting designers. The article also touches on the challenges of creating new productions within the bounds of tradition and the importance of cultural integration in the dance community.

item.title: N.J. Nandini showed why song selection matters too
item.description:
#### Summary of "Trivandrum N.J. Nandini's Music Academy Recital"
Trivandrum N.J. Nandini recently performed a two-hour recital at The Music Academy, showcasing her impressive vocal abilities and song selection. She began with Ambujam Krishna’s ‘Iniyaagilum ninai’ in Purvikalyani, demonstrating clarity in sangatis and showcasing her vocal range in a Hindolam raga alapana. Nandini also presented lesser-heard Swati Tirunal kritis, adding variety to the concert. Her performance of Ragam Tanam Pallavi in raga Bilahari was notable, and she was accompanied by Sriram Sridhar on the violin, Kishore Ramesh on the mridangam, and Karthik Krishnaswamy on the ghatam. While Sriram faced some challenges, he excelled during the RTP. Overall, Nandini's performance was well-received, and her co-artists provided good support and enhanced the presentation with their contributions.
#### Key Points: - Trivandrum N.J. Nandini presented a well-planned two-hour recital at The Music Academy, showcasing her pleasing voice and penchant for song selection. - She demonstrated clarity in sangatis and vocal range in a Hindolam raga alapana. - Nandini presented lesser-heard Swati Tirunal kritis, adding variety to the concert. - Her performance of Ragam Tanam Pallavi in raga Bilahari was notable. - She was accompanied by Sriram Sridhar on the violin, Kishore Ramesh on the mridangam, and Karthik Krishnaswamy on the ghatam. - Sriram faced challenges but excelled during the RTP, and Nandini's co-artists provided good support.

item.title: ‘Devil’ movie review: Nandamuri Kalyan Ram shoulders a half-decent genre bender
item.description:
#### Summary of "Devil - The British Secret Agent" Article
The article discusses the film "Devil - The British Secret Agent," starring Nandamuri Kalyan Ram, and the controversy surrounding the director's credit. The film is described as a serious whodunit investigative thriller set in the pre-Independence era, where the protagonist, Agent Devil, is sent to investigate a murder while also being assigned a mission to intercept a message from freedom fighter Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose. The article praises Kalyan Ram's performance but criticizes the film's overt reliance on dramatic aspects, unnecessary theatrics, and a disappointing climax. Despite some genuine ideas and good twists, the film fails to bring everything together, leaving a poor aftertaste. Overall, the article provides a critical review of "Devil - The British Secret Agent."
[[1]]

item.title: K. Gayatri’s concert was steeped in bhakti
item.description:
The article titled "K. Gayatri's Concert: A Melodious Evening of Ragas Varali and Bhairavi" describes a concert by K. Gayatri, a renowned musician. The concert showcased the beauty and mellow nature of ragas Varali and Bhairavi. Gayatri's performance was praised for her skillful handling of the raga Kamboji and her presentation of Papavinasa Mudaliar's composition, 'Natamadi thirindha'. The article also highlights the contributions of B. Ananthakishnan on the violin and Vijay Natesan on the mridangam, who added vibrant hues and rhythmic support to the concert, respectively. Gayatri's performance included a variety of compositions, ranging from the Dakshinamurthy stotram to Tyagaraja's kriti in Abhogi. The concert concluded with the tillana 'Gowri nayaka' in Kanada. Overall, the concert was a mesmerizing experience that showcased Gayatri's virtuosity and the synergy between the musicians.
Please note that the information provided is a summary of the article and the actual content may contain more details.

item.title: ‘Migration’ movie review: Taking flight on jolly wings
item.description:
The article titled "Migration" is about a movie that features a short film called "Mooned" before the main feature. In "Mooned," the character Vector from "Despicable Me" is marooned on the moon and tries to get off with the help of the Minions. The main feature revolves around a family of mallards who live in a forest in New England. The father, Mack, prefers a quiet life, but his wife, Pam, and their children, Dax and Gwen, are more adventurous. When a family of ducks passing through the pond on their way to Jamaica, Dax becomes infatuated with one of them, Kim. The family decides to embark on an adventure to Jamaica, but they face various challenges along the way, including encounters with other birds and a bejeweled chef. Eventually, they reach Jamaica and see the blue mountains. The movie has excellent voice work, vibrant animation, and the right amount of action. It is currently running in theaters. [[1]](https://www.askamanager.org/2022/01/the-new-hire-who-showed-up-is-not-the-same-person-we-interviewed.html).
#### Key Points: - The movie "Migration" features a short film called "Mooned" before the main feature. - "Mooned" is about the character Vector from "Despicable Me" trying to get off the moon with the help of the Minions. - The main feature revolves around a family of mallards who embark on an adventure to Jamaica. - The movie has excellent voice work, vibrant animation, and the right amount of action.

item.title: Did Malladi Brothers’s experiment pay off?
item.description:
#### Summary of "Malladi Brothers' Performance at Mylapore Fine Arts Club, December 2023"
The Malladi Brothers, Sreeramprasad and Ravikumar, performed at the 72nd year art festival of Mylapore Fine Arts Club in Chennai in December 2023. Their performance was characterized by surprising choices and experimentation, with the use of various ragas and compositions. The concert featured pieces in Kedaram, Sriranjani, Devagandhari, Kantamani, Ananda Bhairavi, Mayamalavagowla, Bilahari, and Pahadi, showcasing a diverse range of musical moods and styles. The brothers demonstrated their traditional repertoire and respect for lyrical expressions, while also allowing for improvisation and creativity within the constraints of certain ragas. The accompanying musicians, including violinist Karthik Nagaraj, Ghatam Suresh, and K.V. Gopalakrishnan, contributed to the overall success of the performance with their skillful and engaging accompaniment.
The concert was noted for its experimentation and the brothers' ability to create various moods through their choice of ragas. The performance was a blend of traditional repertoire and innovative selections, showcasing the Malladi Brothers' musical versatility and skill.
Overall, the Malladi Brothers' performance at the Mylapore Fine Arts Club in December 2023 was characterized by surprising choices, experimentation, and a blend of traditional and innovative musical elements.
[[1]]

item.title: The Akkarai Sisters concert: Some leisurely moments would have enhanced the appeal
item.description:
The article discusses the concert performance of the Akkarai Sisters, S. Subhalakshmi and S. Sornalatha, accompanied by Patri Satish Kumar on the mridangam, Kamalakiran on the violin, and Krishna Sairam on the ghatam. The concert had both positive and negative aspects. While the sisters showcased technical accomplishments and rapid tempos, the performance lacked pleasantness and sensitivity. The article highlights specific songs and their renditions during the concert, such as 'Seethamma mayamma' in Vasantha and 'Karunakari devi kamakshi' in Sumanesa Ranjani. The Akkarai Sisters demonstrated their manodharma skills and musical instinct, but the article suggests that they may need to reflect on their overall style and identity. The concert also featured Kamalakiran's impressive raga alapana and laya skills, while Krishna Sairam added energetic touches on the ghatam. Overall, the article suggests that the concert had its strengths but also room for improvement [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/music/the-akkarai-sisters-concert-some-leisurely-moments-would-have-enhanced-the-appeal/article67680299.ece).

item.description: The Sangeetha Parishath Mangalore recently celebrated its 30th anniversary with a five-day festival called 'Thrimshath Sambhrama'. Ramya Kiranmayi Chaganti from Visakhapatnam also showcased her talent, focusing on patantara, diction, and raga bhava. The article highlights the performances of both artists, along with the accompanying musicians.

item.title: Radhika Shurajit’s new production is based on popular songs on Muruga
item.description: The article discusses the recent staging of the dance production 'Kanda Kadamba Kathirvela' in Chennai, which was part of the Skanda Sashti celebrations. Directed and choreographed by Radhika Shurajit, the performance depicted the popular hymn 'Kanda Sashti Kavacham' and other songs dedicated to Muruga. The first composition focused on the birth of Muruga, who is believed to have emerged from sparks that came from Shiva's third eye. The production featured six girls representing the six maidens who raised the babies, creating an impressive visual representation. Popular songs on Muruga were chosen to engage the audience, with energetic movements dominating the choreography. The depiction of the healing process described in the hymn was well-executed using masks to represent evil forces. However, some of the songs chosen were not suitable for dance choreography, leading to repetitive expressions and movements. The production concluded with a Lalgudi Jayaraman thillana and the Thiruppugazh 'Nada vindhu kaladi.' The music and lighting design added to the overall impact of the performance.

item.title: ‘Wish’ movie review: A sweet yet shallow ride to nostalgia
item.description: The article discusses the animated film "Wish," which pays tribute to old-school Walt Disney animation. The film showcases talking animals, a brave protagonist named Asha, and vibrant colors reminiscent of classic Disney films. Asha lives in Rosas, a country ruled by a magician named Magnifico, where people come to have their wishes granted during a monthly ceremony. As Asha questions Magnifico's policy of not granting certain wishes, she inadvertently sets off a chain of events that impact Rosas and its citizens. Ultimately, the film delivers a message that simply wishing for something does not guarantee it will come true. Although the movie has a charming aesthetic, some find its moralizing slightly cynical. Overall, "Wish" is currently playing in theaters.

The film is set in an Orwellian world where the government controls everything, and individuals have no agency over their lives. Tovino Thomas delivers an exceptional performance as the nameless protagonist who lives alone in an abandoned railway coach. Nimisha Sajayan also shines as the nameless woman living nearby. Tovino's character can communicate with the dead at the mortuary where he works, providing insights into their lives and deaths. The narrative is the highlight of the film, but Tovino's performance stands out. The article praises his versatility and physical transformation for the role. item.title: ‘The Railway Men’ series review: A bracing, wishful saga of bravery
item.description:
The article discusses the new Netflix series "The Railway Men" and provides a summary of its plot and themes. The show is inspired by the 1984 Bhopal gas leak tragedy, which killed thousands of people and is considered one of the worst industrial disasters in history. The story follows a group of Indian Railways employees who conduct a daring rescue operation to save a fraction of the population after toxic gas escapes from a nearby chemical plant.
The main character is Iftekaar Siddiqui, an honest and haunted stationmaster who witnesses the chaos caused by the gas leak. With the help of other railway workers, he tries to contact neighboring stations to stop an incoming train and arrange a rescue mission. The series also highlights the greed and negligence that led to the disaster, with the Union Carbide factory's safety controls being in disorder.
The article mentions that the series touches upon other events happening in India during that time, such as the assassination of Indira Gandhi and the subsequent anti-Sikh violence. It also draws parallels to current times, including references to COVID-19 precautions.
The performances of Kay Kay Menon, R Madhavan, and Divyenndu are praised, along with the cinematography that creates a somber atmosphere. However, the camera angles and spins are described as disorienting, especially when watching on a small screen.
The article concludes by emphasizing the personal struggles of the characters and their dedication to their duties. The unity between the Indian Railways and the people of Bhopal is highlighted, although the religious background of the characters is not explicitly focused on in the series.
"The Railway Men" is available for streaming on Netflix.

However, there are some criticisms, including the underutilization of veteran actor Brahmanandam's character. Overall, the article describes "Keedaa Cola" as a chaotic yet enjoyable comedy.

item.title: ‘Fingernails’ movie review: Sci-fi romance tests humanity against technology, but plays it too safe
item.description: The article discusses the film "Fingernails" available for streaming on AppleTV+. The movie presents a world where couples test their compatibility before entering a relationship, labeling themselves as 'positive' or 'negative'. The story revolves around Anna and Ryan, a couple with a 100% positive result, and Anna's growing disconnection from Ryan as she starts working at a clinic. The film explores the frictions that arise when love is quantified through technology but doesn't fully delve into a range of emotions. While the film offers an immersive experience and blends eerie and absurd elements seamlessly, it could have benefited from a more tonally diverse ending. Jessie Buckley's performance as Anna stands out, conveying her yearning and restlessness.

item.title: ‘Monster’ movie review: A truth in three acts in Hirokazu Kore-eda’s moral drama
item.description: The article discusses the film "Monster" directed by Hirokazu Kore-eda. The film revolves around a single mother named Saori and her son Minato, who begins to exhibit troubling behavior after witnessing a fire. Saori suspects Minato's homeroom teacher, Mr. Hori, of being the "monster" responsible for her son's changes. However, as the narrative progresses, different perspectives are presented, challenging the initial assumptions. The article highlights how the film emphasizes the power of language and the devastating effects of subtle cruelties. It also mentions the film's connection to Kore-eda's previous work, particularly "Shoplifters," and pays tribute to composer Ryuichi Sakamoto, who passed away.

item.title: ‘EA Sports FC 2024’ game review: New name, old problems
item.description: The article discusses the latest installment of EA Sports FIFA, called EA Sports FC 24. The author praises the game's evolution over the years, incorporating real-time physics and motion-captured players. They particularly highlight the new technologies introduced in FC 24 but also urge EA to reconsider their controversial loot box strategies. The review focuses on the next-generation consoles and PC versions, mentioning that the Nintendo Switch version has limitations. The article mentions the return of popular features like Career Mode and Manager Mode, as well as the inclusion of women's teams in the Ultimate Team mode. The improvements in player movement and realism are attributed to the Hypermotion V system and Play Styles+. However, the goalkeeper AI is criticized for occasional mistakes. The article also addresses the controversy surrounding loot boxes in the game, cautioning players about the potential financial implications of engaging with this feature. The visuals of FC 24 are lauded, with lifelike player animations and beautifully rendered pitches.

item.title: ‘Pain Hustlers’ movie review: Chris Evans and Emily Blunt can’t save this mediocre drama on meds
item.description: The article discusses the film "Pain Hustlers," starring Chris Evans and Emily Blunt. The author criticizes the film for its predictable storyline and lackluster moments. Blunt's performance is praised, but the rest of the cast is said to have very little to do. The article compares "Pain Hustlers" to "The Wolf of Wall Street" and mentions the disappointment of seeing talented performers not getting their due. Overall, the film is described as a forgettable drama.The article discusses the film "Pain Hustlers," starring Chris Evans and Emily Blunt. It mentions that Evans' post-superhero career hasn't been great, and this film continues that trend. Blunt, on the other hand, delivers a strong performance but is let down by a predictable storyline and lackluster moments in the film. The plot revolves around Blunt's character, Liza Drake, a single mother trying to improve her life by getting involved with a sinking pharmaceutical company. However, things take a turn for the worse, leading to the downfall of Liza. The article compares the film to "The Wolf of Wall Street" but criticizes "Pain Hustlers" for lacking the audacity and excitement of the former. Despite a talented cast, the film fails to provide them with substantial material. Overall, the article describes "Pain Hustlers" as a forgettable drama that leaves the audience disappointed.

item.title: ‘Masterpeace’ series review: A loud, humorous antidote for regressive television serials
item.description: "Masterpeace" is a Malayalam OTT series that deviates from the typical formula of long-running, regressive television serials. The show focuses on a young couple whose overbearing parents intervene in their lives. The series incorporates elements of Wes Anderson's movie aesthetics, with colorful and quirky production design. The conflicts between the generations and lifestyles are treated with humor rather than melodrama. The series promotes progressive values and encourages the older generation to update themselves. Overall, "Masterpeace" serves as a partial antidote to traditional television serials but falls short of its potential.

item.title: ‘Pulimada’ movie review: This thriller is a Joju George show all the way
item.description: The article discusses the Malayalam film "Pulimada" directed by AK Saajan. The film revolves around the life of Vincent Skaria, a policeman who lives alone and longs for a life partner. However, his traditionalist and chauvinistic views hinder his search for a wife. After his marriage gets fixed but the bride elopes, Vincent goes on a rampage. He encounters a free-spirited woman named Mahishmati, and strange incidents unfold after he brings her home. The film explores Vincent's mind as the tiger's den, and the lead actor Joju George delivers a powerful performance. The article highlights the film's flaws in the climax but praises its overall milieu and performances.

item.title: ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ movie review: Martin Scorsese’s slow-burn look at the troubling birth of enterprise is frustratingly opaque
item.description: The article discusses Martin Scorsese's latest film, "Killers of the Flower Moon," which is based on the true story of the murders of Osage people in the 1920s after oil was discovered on their land. The film stars Leonardo DiCaprio and Robert De Niro and explores the investigation into these killings. The author finds the film visually stunning and praises its production design and score. The acting performances, particularly by DiCaprio and De Niro, are also praised. However, the author criticizes the lack of character motivation and development for the Osage people in the film. Overall, despite its long runtime, "Killers of the Flower Moon" is considered a compelling watch.

item.title: ‘Otta’ movie review: Resul Pookutty’s directorial debut fails to make a mark, despite its lofty intentions
item.description: "Otta" is a film about runaway children, based on the real-life story of businessman S Hariharan. The characters in the film are depicted as troubled loners running away from various situations, such as toxic parenting and a horrible workplace. The screenplay, however, is described as uneven and lacking engagement. The characters' traumatic lives and the bleakness they face are portrayed without much hope, and the philosophical ruminations on life come across as hollow. The conflicts and reasons for the characters drifting apart are under-written, and some of the parents' opposition to their friendship feels forced. Despite its intentions to highlight the plight of runaway children, the film struggles to evoke emotional response from viewers.

item.title: ‘Tagaru Palya’ movie review: An old-fashioned village drama with a few laughs
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the film "Tagaru Palya," directed by Umesh K Krupa. The story revolves around a village community gathered for a feast, where the protagonist's daughter decides to elope with her lover. The film takes place over one day, but fails to deliver on its promising premise. The portrayal of villagers and city-born people is stereotypical and lacks depth. The central characters lack personality, and the film becomes preachy when it delves into message-heavy scenes. item.title: ‘Tejas’ movie review: Kangana Ranaut’s surgical strike goes kaput
item.description: The article discusses the film "Tejas," starring Kangana Ranaut, and criticizes its lackluster execution and weak plot. The film aims to promote nationalist feelings and trust in women officers in combat operations but falls short in delivering an engaging narrative. The article mentions that the film focuses more on Kangana's character's aviators and swagger on the tarmac rather than generating breathtaking action in the air. The performances in the film are also deemed uneven, with only a few exceptions. Overall, the article suggests that "Tejas" is not a successful endeavor.

item.title: ‘Martin Luther King’ movie review: Sampoornesh Babu’s sharp political satire is a timely reminder of the power of voting
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. The film explores the themes of politics, caste, and class, emphasizing the importance of voting as a means to bring about social change. The story revolves around a village divided into two warring groups, with Sampoornesh Babu playing the title role. The film highlights the discrimination faced by lower castes and the apathy prevalent in society. item.title: ‘How is That For a Monday?’ movie review: A heartwarming story of race, identity and humanity
item.description: The article discusses the film "How is That for a Monday?", a Telugu-English American indie film directed by Sripal Sama. The film tells the story of Shyam Kumar, a young H-1B visa-holding immigrant, as he navigates through a series of unfortunate events on a Monday. The film explores themes of multicultural identities and touches on the aftermath of the George Floyd incident and Black Lives Matter protests. The article praises the performances of the cast, particularly Kaushik Ghantasala as Shyam, and applauds the directorial debut of Sripal Sama.

item.title: ‘12th Fail’ movie review: Vidhu Vinod Chopra delivers yet another hug of hope that is more earnest than magical
item.description: The article discusses the film "12th Fail," directed by Vidhu Vinod Chopra. The film tells the story of Manoj Kumar Sharma, a young man from Chambal who overcomes poverty and corruption to pursue his dreams. The article praises the film for its celebration of probity and human goodness, comparing it to Chopra's previous films "Munna Bhai M.B.B.S." and "3 Idiots." It highlights the film's portrayal of everyday discrimination and dehumanization faced by the underprivileged and the challenges they encounter in seeking positions of power. The article also mentions the film's depiction of bias against candidates from vernacular backgrounds in the Union Public Service Commission exam. It commends Vikrant Massey's performance as Manoj, emphasizing his ability to convey emotions through his eyes. However, the article criticizes the film for some similarities to "3 Idiots" and suggests that the editing could have been sharper. Overall, the article recommends "12th Fail" as an important film deserving of attention.

item.title: ‘Upload’ season 3 review: Greg Daniels is back with more giggles and gigabytes of social consciousness
item.description: The article discusses the second season of the science fiction comedy series "Upload." The show is set in the future where humans can upload their consciousness to a digital afterlife. The protagonist, Nathan, is downloaded back into the real world with the help of his girlfriend, Ingrid. The article explores the challenges Nathan faces in balancing his relationships in both the digital and real worlds. The season also introduces new characters and storylines, including a new villain. The writing is praised for its sharpness and humor. The article concludes by mentioning that a fourth season has been ordered. "Upload" season 3 is currently streaming on Amazon Prime Video.

item.title: ‘Doona!’ K-Drama review: Bae Suzy is at her best in this nuanced coming-of-age story
item.description: The article discusses the South Korean drama series "Doona!", focusing on its themes of friendship, companionship, and healing. The show explores the life of Lee Doo-na, a celebrity vocalist on hiatus, and her growing friendship with Lee Won-jun, a college student who becomes her housemate. The article praises the nuanced and mature storytelling of the show, as well as the performances of the cast, particularly Bae Suzy in the role of Doo-na. It also highlights the show's ability to go beyond the typical love triangle narrative and its memorable OST. The article concludes by stating that "Doona!" is currently streaming on Netflix.

item.title: It’s fine to fall asleep at this concert
item.description: The article discusses a unique lullaby concert held in Bengaluru, India, by singers Vedanth Bharadwaj and Gurupriya Atreya. The concert aimed to provide relaxation and healing to the audience by inviting them to switch off and simply relax. The lullabies chosen depicted scenes from the lives of caregivers, parents, and lovers, cutting through barriers of time, location, age, language, culture, and class. The singers emphasized the importance of being relaxed and meditative while singing lullabies. The article also highlights the "Sing a Lullaby" project, which started during the lockdown and brought together a community of lullaby enthusiasts to teach and learn lullabies. The concert stood out for its inclusive approach, crediting musicians, researchers, and folk practitioners who taught the lullabies. The singers also created a unique concert experience by eliminating the stage, dressing down, and enveloping the audience with carefully curated, low volume sound. The article notes that, impressively, the audience was so captivated that they didn't applaud during the concert.

item.title: ‘The Pigeon Tunnel’ documentary review: A fascinating portrait of a spy as a novelist
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. The film explores Cornwell's difficult upbringing, his career in the intelligence service, and the inspirations behind his famous books. The title of the film refers to the pigeons bred on the roof of a castle in Monte Carlo, symbolizing the cyclical nature of life. The documentary includes dramatic recreations, interviews, and film clips from adaptations of Le Carré's works. "The Pigeon Tunnel" is available for streaming on Apple TV+.

item.title: ‘Old Dads’ movie review: Bill Burr and Co’s uphill battle against political correctness is a misfire
item.description: The article discusses the film "Old Dads" directed by comedian Bill Burr. The film revolves around a group of friends/business partners who find themselves struggling in the modern world after losing their business. The article criticizes the film for being filled with clichés and lacking in humor. It compares the film to another similar comedy that failed to make an impact. The article suggests that the film's attempt to tackle social issues falls flat and would have been better if it stuck to a more light-hearted approach. The film is currently streaming on Netflix.

item.title: ‘Bodies’ Netflix series review: Stephen Graham’s time-travelling whodunnit just about brings it home
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the Netflix mini-series "Bodies," which is an adaptation of Si Spencer's graphic novel. The show follows four different detectives in different timelines, all connected by a single body that appears in each time period. The article praises the show's ambitious scope and ability to juggle multiple timelines and intricate plot points. It mentions the use of split screens and continuous panels to juxtapose different narrative threads. While the plot is engaging and full of surprising reveals, the article criticizes the lack of character development and thinness of some characters. Overall, the article highlights the camaraderie between the detectives across time as a standout aspect of the show. "Bodies" is currently streaming on Netflix.

item.title: ‘The Other Zoey’ movie review: Josephine Langford lights up this knowing, modern love story
item.description: The article discusses the film "The Other Zoey" and describes it as a sweet and comforting rom-com. The story revolves around Zoey, a high-achieving computer geek, who believes that relationships built on compatibility have a better chance of surviving than those based on romantic love. When she meets a student named Miles who shares her views, complications arise when she causes another student, Zach, to have a concussion and amnesia. The article praises the pleasant performances of the cast and mentions the presence of Heather Graham and Andie MacDowell as the best kind of movie moms. Overall, the article concludes that the film offers an enjoyable 90-minute experience.

item.title: ‘Ganapath’ movie review: Tiger Shroff struggles to salvage this still-born franchise
item.description: The article discusses the film "Ganapath" starring Tiger Shroff and directed by Vikas Bahl. It suggests that despite the film's ambitious idea of a dystopian world and a local superhero franchise, it fails to deliver a compelling storyline and credible execution. The article criticizes the mediocrity of the film, including the editing, music, and visual effects. It also mentions that the characters lack depth, and the performances of Kriti Sanon and Amitabh Bachchan are underutilized. Overall, the article concludes that "Ganapath" falls short in creating emotional impact and fails to engage the audience.

item.title: ‘Tiger Nageswara Rao’ movie review: Vamsee and Ravi Teja’s ambitious biopic-style drama is occasionally interesting
item.description: The article is a review of the Telugu film "Tiger Nageswara Rao" directed by Vamsee. The film tells the story of Nageswara Rao, a dacoit in Stuartpuram, Andhra Pradesh. The director relied on accounts from the late dacoit's wife and others in the village and police to create the narrative. However, the film presents black and white characters instead of a complex portrayal, which takes away from its potential. The film includes jaw-dropping sequences but suffers from subpar visual effects. It delves into the rise of Nageswara Rao and his battles with a local politician and police officer. The review praises some heist sequences and production design but criticizes the portrayal of women and the repetitive violence. Ravi Teja's performance as the title character is praised, while other actors have little to do. The reviewer wishes that the film hadn't watered down the story into a generic Robin Hood tale.

item.title: Jayanthi Kumaresh’s veena never fails to delight the audience
item.description: The article discusses a recent performance by senior veena artist Jayanthi Kumaresh at the centenary celebrations of K.V. Narayanaswamy. The article highlights Jayanthi's technical prowess and innovative methods of manodharma, including her use of frets to access higher swaras and her exploration of lesser-known ragas. The article also praises the accompanying musicians, Bangalore Arjun Kumar on the mridangam and Trichy Krishnaswamy on the ghatam, for their competent support. The article suggests that while Jayanthi's performances are of high quality, there is a desire among audiences for more variety in terms of ragas and kritis. The concert concluded with compositions in Behag and Dwijavanti.

item.title: ‘Ghost’ movie review: Shivarajkumar shines in a potent yet complicated fanboy tribute
item.description: The article discusses the film "Ghost" directed by MG Srinivas, focusing on the performance of Kannada superstar Shivarajkumar. The director highlights Shivarajkumar's style, characterized by a sleek hairstyle, blue contact lenses, and elegant outfits, as well as positioning him as a larger-than-life personality. The film revolves around two political parties in conflict over the privatization of a jail, with Shivarajkumar's character holding a prominent figure hostage. While the film celebrates Shivarajkumar's screen presence, the article criticizes the screenplay for being oscillating between layered and incomprehensible. The non-linear screenplay is seen as overstuffed, with abrupt transitions that prevent deeper engagement. However, the film's fast-paced narration and entertaining elements make it worth watching for those seeking pure entertainment. The article also mentions the film's background score and action sequences, praising the performance of actor Jayaram. Overall, the film is seen as an ambitious attempt deserving of appreciation, despite its flaws.

item.title: ‘Bhagavanth Kesari’ movie review: Anil Ravipudi, Balakrishna outing is a middling action family drama
item.description: The article discusses the Telugu movie "Bhagavanth Kesari" directed by Anil Ravipudi and starring Nandamuri Balakrishna and Sreeleela. The director aimed to create a film that would appeal beyond Balakrishna's fanbase. The story follows Nelakonda Bhagavanth Kesari, played by Balakrishna, who becomes a father figure to Vijayalakshmi (Sreeleela) and helps her overcome anxiety to join the Indian Army. The film includes messages of women empowerment but also presents regressive elements. Additionally, there are subplots involving a business tycoon and themes of revenge. Balakrishna's character remains invincible throughout the action-packed film, with numerous punch dialogues. item.title: ‘Kaala Paani’ series review: Ambitious survival drama reaches the shore

item.title: ‘Goosebumps’ series review: No lack of fun, thrill and worms in this binge-worthy teen horror comedy
item.description: The article discusses the Disney+ series "Goosebumps," based on R. L. Stine's book series. The show initially appears generic and predictable but surprises viewers with novel ideas and a binge-worthy teen horror drama. The story revolves around a group of teens who break into an abandoned villa on Halloween night and encounter supernatural events. Each character's personal struggles are intertwined with the horrors they face. As the teens piece together the mystery, they discover the involvement of the adults in their lives. The article praises the series for its supernatural elements, character dynamics, and genre-bending scenes. It anticipates more thrilling episodes, innovative character designs, and gore.

item.title: ‘Dumb Money’ movie review: Paul Dano, Pete Davidson shine in laugh-riot on the GameStop short squeeze
item.description: The article discusses the film "Dumb Money" directed by Craig Gillespie, which is based on the 2021 GameStop short squeeze. The film tells the story of Keith Gill, a marketing professional and YouTuber who invests in GameStop stocks and sparks a revolution among retail investors. It portrays the impact of online communities like Reddit's WallStreetBets on the financial world and highlights the struggle between small investors and hedge funds. The article praises the film for its fast pace, engaging storytelling, and strong performances. It also notes the irony of the movie industry capitalizing on an event that ridiculed the top 1% and highlights the emotional depth brought to the characters. Overall, the article recommends "Dumb Money" as an entertaining and well-made film.

item.title: ‘The Fall of the House of Usher’ series review: For a change, Mike Flanagan roots for horror
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info."The Fall of the House of Usher" is a show by Mike Flanagan that explores themes of greed, justice, and revenge. The story follows Roderick Usher and his sister Madeline, who head a pharmaceutical company being sued for the opioid crisis. As tensions rise within the family, their children start dying one by one. The show unfolds as a tale being told by Roderick to the prosecutor, recounting the deaths of the Usher heirs. Each episode is an adaptation of a different Edgar Allan Poe tale, and Flanagan delivers a unique blend of psychological mayhem and supernatural justice. The show deviates from Flanagan's previous works, offering a more vindictive and revenge-driven narrative. While the episodic format and large cast of characters may have some drawbacks, the performances, particularly by Carla Gugino, elevate the show. "The Fall of the House of Usher" can be streamed on Netflix.

item.title: ‘Lessons in Chemistry’ series review: Brie Larson headlines a quaint tale that is organic, but struggles to create a bond
item.description: "Lessons in Chemistry" is a limited series adaptation of the bestselling book by Bonnie Garmus. The story, set in the 1950s, follows Elizabeth Zott, a genius chemist who faces adversity and forms a connection with Calvin Evans in a university lab. The series explores their relationship and the extraordinary events that unfold. Brie Larson delivers an excellent performance as Zott, and her character's unique relationship with cooking adds depth to the plot. While the book effectively navigates back-and-forth movements, the series sometimes feels jerky and lacks coherence. The portrayal of Harriet Sloane as a young black American activist seems disconnected from the overall narrative. The series rushes certain reveals and relies on coincidences, which can be inconsistent and less satisfying than the book. Despite its flaws, "Lessons in Chemistry" features strong performances, great music, and visuals, making it worth watching.

item.title: ‘Dhak Dhak’ movie review: A well-meaning but patchy tale of female empowerment
item.description: The article discusses the film "Dhak Dhak" and its portrayal of female bikers on adventurous journeys. The director, Tarun Dudeja, tells the story of four women who embark on a challenging journey from Delhi to Khardung La. While the backstories of some characters make sense, others are harder to believe. The screenplay follows a predictable route with obstacles faced by the women along the way. However, the film remains engaging due to the competent cast and their humorous dialogues and observations on life and relationships. Overall, "Dhak Dhak" offers a mix of entertainment and a commentary on women's empowerment.

item.title: ‘The Burial’ movie review: Jamie Foxx is on point in this engaging legal drama
item.description: The article discusses the film "The Burial," in which Jamie Foxx plays an attorney named Willie Gary. The character has a strong professional reputation and hasn't lost a case in 12 years. However, his invincibility is tested when he takes on a challenging case involving a contractual dispute. The film is described as an engaging courtroom drama that goes beyond the typical genre. It explores themes of racism, corporate politics, and capitalism. Despite some predictability, the film's big-heartedness is praised. "The Burial" is currently streaming on Prime Video.

item.title: ‘Assassin’s Creed Mirage’ game review: Returning to the roots of stealth and intrigue
item.description: The article discusses the upcoming game "Assassin's Creed Mirage" and how it aims to bring the series back to its roots. Set in ninth-century Baghdad, the game follows the story of Basim Ibn Ishaq, a character familiar to those who played "Assassin's Creed Valhalla." The game focuses on Basim's journey from a street thief to a high-ranking assassin, with the main conflict being against the order of the ancients, the predecessors of the templars. While the storyline is straightforward and lacks standout moments, it retains the typical Assassin's Creed progression. The game emphasizes stealth-oriented gameplay, bringing back beloved stealth and parkour elements that had been downplayed in recent RPG-focused titles. Despite having a smaller map compared to previous games, Baghdad is beautifully crafted and offers a more intimate experience for classic Assassin's Creed fans. Overall, "Assassin's Creed Mirage" shows promise for the series' future by returning to the series' roots.

item.title: T.N. Seshagopalan on how he was inspired by Harikesanallur Muthiah Bhagavatar’s versatility
item.description: The Nadasurabhi Cultural Association in Bengaluru celebrated the 75th birthday of musician Madurai T.N. Seshagopalan, honoring him with a Lifetime Achievement Award. The event included reminiscences from senior artists who have worked with Seshagopalan, as well as insights from his disciples and colleagues. A short film highlighting his life and experiences was presented by his son and disciple, T.N.S. Krishna. Seshagopalan spoke about his guru, Harikesanallur Muthiah Bhagavatar, and his contributions to classical music and harikatha. He discussed Bhagavatar's compositions, journey as a performer of Harikatha, and his notable features as a composer. item.title: ‘The Vaccine War’ movie review: Nana Patekar and Pallavi Joshi drive this toolkit of a film
item.description: "The Vaccine War" is a film that celebrates the efforts of Indian scientists in developing an indigenous vaccine against COVID-19. However, it turns into a rant against critics of the government's vaccine development process and questions their commitment to science. The film incorporates conspiracy theories, presenting a science editor named Rohini Singh Dhulia as a cardboard villain who aims to create doubts about the Indian vaccine with the help of foreign sponsors. The film highlights the commitment and courage of the scientists involved but selectively focuses on the government's efforts to be self-reliant in vaccine manufacturing without acknowledging the country's robust vaccination program. Despite some engaging moments and emotional storytelling, the film becomes more focused on countering skeptics rather than addressing important issues. It fails to discuss the scientific advantages of the government's actions during the initial days of the pandemic or acknowledge global vaccine hesitancy and other factors contributing to the challenges faced. Overall, "The Vaccine War" adds to the existing information overload rather than providing a balanced narrative.

item.title: ‘Kumari Srimathi’ web series review: A superb Nithya Menen anchors a tale of rural entrepreneurship with a dash of humour
item.description: The Telugu web series "Kumari Srimathi" explores a side of East Godavari that mainstream Telugu cinema would hesitate to delve into. The seven-episode series, available on Amazon Prime Video, focuses on rural entrepreneurship and breaks stereotypes with humor. The story revolves around a dysfunctional family, led by Nithya Menen's character, Srimathi, who bravely confronts the challenges brought about by irresponsible and greedy men. The series showcases three generations of women dealing with difficult situations in their own unique ways. Srimathi's determination to win back her ancestral house leads her to open a bar in the village, which presents various obstacles to overcome. Despite some simplified resolutions and predictable male characters, the series shines through its multifaceted female protagonists. Overall, "Kumari Srimathi" offers an enjoyable viewing experience, highlighting the strength and resilience of its women.

item.title: ‘Chithha’ movie review: Siddharth stars in a painfully-relevant and poignantly-brilliant drama
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the film "Chithha" directed by SU Arun Kumar and starring Siddharth. The film explores the bond between a niece and her uncle and delves into themes of child abuse and sexual assault. The director's skill in writing relationships is highlighted, along with the strong performances from the cast. The article praises the depiction of abuse behind closed doors and the realistic portrayal of legal proceedings in a POCSO case. The conflicts faced by the protagonist are outlined, including accusations of sexual abuse and the kidnapping of the niece. The article also mentions the importance of the film's messages regarding identity and reactions to sexual abuse. Overall, "Chithha" is described as an important and impactful film.

item.title: ‘Baanadariyalli’ movie review: This Ganesh, Rukmini Vasanth romance fails to hit the heights
item.description: The article discusses the Kannada film "Baanadariyalli" directed by Preetham Gubbi and starring Ganesh and Rukmini Vasanth. The film revolves around the dreams of loved ones, love, acceptance, and self-realization. However, the article criticizes the film's execution, highlighting Gubbi's poor writing and directing. The chemistry between the lead actors is questioned, with the characters' love story lacking depth and meaningful moments. The article also mentions that the film attempts adventure in Masai Mara but fails to use the location effectively. Overall, the article suggests that the film falls short of expectations and raises questions about the future of both the director and the actor.

item.title: ‘Charlie Chopra & The Mystery of Solang Valley’ series review: An elementary whodunit
item.description: The article discusses the film "Charlie Chopra & The Mystery of Solang Valley," directed by Vishal Bhardwaj. The film is an adaptation of Agatha Christie's "The Sittaford Mystery" and follows the character of Charlie, played by Wamiqa Gabbi, who becomes an amateur sleuth to prove her fiancé's innocence in a murder case. The article praises Wamiqah Gabbi's performance and highlights her talent and charm as an actor. However, it criticizes the use of direct address to the audience, comparing it unfavorably to the technique used in the TV show Fleabag. The article also mentions that the film incorporates Indian elements and references, giving it a unique touch. In conclusion, the article suggests that if future seasons are made, the film has the potential to change the game for female detectives in Hindi cinema.

item.title: ‘Cassandro’ movie review: Gael García Bernal shines bright in this feel-good biopic
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the film "Cassandro," which tells the story of Saúl Armendáriz, a gay wrestler in the 1980s who broke into the world of Mexican professional wrestling. The protagonist, played by Gael García Bernal, lives with his mother in El Paso, Texas, and travels to Mexico to participate in Lucha Libre. He decides to fight as an exótico (a wrestler who fights in drag) and takes on the stage name Cassandro. The film explores Saúl's journey, his relationships, and the impact he has on opening doors for gay wrestlers. The article praises Bernal's performance and highlights the film's depiction of the popular world of Lucha Libre. While some liberties are taken with the facts, the overall movie experience is described as beautiful and enjoyable. "Cassandro" is currently available for streaming on Prime Video.
